title: Academic Skills Centre
content:
Want to improve your mathematical, academic writing and general academic skills? The Academic Skills Centre (ASC) can help you develop as a learner.

Visit the ASC at the Main Library, first floor, to get personal advice or sign up for a workshop.

  • ASC workshops coming up
  • Find out more about the ASC

title: Active Lifestyle classes
content:
Our dedicated dance studio hosts over 24 hours of classes a week. Located on the lower ground floor of the Munrow Sports Centre, it measures 18 x 15m, has full length mirrors, a ballet barre, music system and equipment for exercise to music classes and circuit training. Boom.

Find out about Active Lifestyle Classes

Book online for Active Lifestyle Classes

title: Advice and Representation Centre
content:
The ARC provides free, impartial and confidential information, advice and representation on a wide range of issues to all students.

Whatever the question – or difficulty – we’ll always try to help and if we can’t we’re sure to know someone who can, within or outside the Guild or University.

Location: Ground Floor, Guild of Students
Email: thearc@guild.bham.ac.uk
Tel: 0121 251 2400
Find out more: ARC website

Opening hours

  • Vacation: Monday–Friday, 12noon–2pm

title: Bookings
content:
Bookings can be made online

When booking ensure you remember your ID card. Please remember to keep your receipt.

Booking at the Munrow Reception

Bookings for the courts/pitches for less than an hour can be booked at theMunrow Reception. Bookings can only be made by members seven days in advance or less.

Bookings can be made for; Squash, Badminton & Tennis Courts, Sports Hall & New Gym, Water-based synthetic pitches, 3rd generation synthetic pitches.

Open: Monday-Friday, 10am-4pm.
Tel: +44 (0)121 414 4117.

Please note that phone bookings must be paid for, at the time of booking, by either credit or debit card.

Equipment hire

Equipment such as rackets and balls may be hired from the Munrow reception as can lockers in the changing rooms on a long-term basis.

title: Buses
content:
There are eight local bus services serving the University directly every hour. Numbers 61, X62, 63 and X64 travel to the University’s Edgbaston and Selly Oak campuses via the Bristol Road, while the 636 serves the Medical School and Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The services all run frequently from the city centre.

Numbers 76, 84 and 448 serve the Medical School providing links to areas such as Solihull, Kings Norton, Harborne, Bearwood and Cotteridge.

Find out more about bus services:

  • Network West Midlands timetable
  • National Express West Midlands

title: Campus security
content:
Campus Security is available 24/7, 365 days a year. The University’s Security Control room can be contacted on +44 (0)121 414 3000 (43000 if dialing internally). In the event of an emergency use the emergency line +44 (0)121 414 4444 (44444 internally). It’s a good idea to put these numbers on speed dial in your mobile phone.

  • Fire: contact Security Control on 44444.
  • Ambulance: call 999, and then inform Security Control on 44444 so that they can get the ambulance to you quickly.
  • Police: dial 999 and then inform Security Control.

If you are suspicious about possible terrorist activity call the Anti-Terrorist Confidential Hotline on ++44 (0)800 789 321.

If you would like to report information about a crime you can contact the police Crimestoppers Line on ++44 (0)800 555 111. All calls are in confidence and you don’t have to give your name.

The University has its own Confidential Crime Line. Call ++44 (0)121 414 7500 (47500 internally) to report crimes in confidence.

Location: Security Office, Aston Webb Building.

title: Canvas
content:
Canvas is the University’s virtual learning environment (VLE). Online learning materials for your courses should be available via Canvas.

title: Car parking
content:
Student car parking permits are issued according to 'needs based' criteria. A student will be eligible for a parking permit if they meet one or more of the following criteria:

  • Your term time address is over 10 miles away from the University.
  • You are registered disabled (evidence will be required).
  • You are a Carer or a Guardian: Students who are the parents or legal guardians of children under 16 years of age who live at the term-time address and/or students who must regularly attend elderly parents, or parents with a disability, as a registered carer at their permanent home address (evidence will be required).
  • Students with other certified medical reasons (medical evidence will be required).

Apply for a student car parking permit

Permit holders are only permitted to park in the North Car Park (access via Pritchatts Rd) and in the Pritchatts Road Car Park (corner of Pritchatts Rd and Vincent Drive).

Car parking costs £1.00 per day, pay and display Monday to Friday until 4.30pm.

Students who do not hold a permit but require out-of-hours car parking on campus please contact carparking@bham.ac.uk

Location: Car Parking Records, 1st Floor Staff House
Tel : +44 (0) 121 414 2623
Email: carparking@bham.ac.uk

Opening hours

Monday to Thursday 9.30am - 4pm

title: Careers
content:
The University’s employability service can help with careers advice, mock interviews, CV writing and more. The service offers a range of careers-related resources, including an information room with a resource library and access to computing facilities including programmes to help with career decision making, funding, further study and online testing.

Tel: 0121 414 6120
Location: University Centre
Careers and Employability Centre website

title: Community wardens
content:
Community wardens promote community relations in the local area so that everyone can feel a sense of pride in their community. If you live in Selly Oak you’ll have a team of wardens who promote safety, crime awareness and recycling.

Find out more: Community wardens

title: Counselling and wellbeing
content:
The Counselling and Wellbeing Service provides counselling for all registered students in order to help you engage more effectively in your academic and social environment and to be sufficiently free from psychological distress to achieve your full potential. The service also runs groups and workshops to help students adjust to life at university.

Apart from issues associated with settling in to a new environment we also help with other problems such as depression, anxiety, flat mate issues, eating problems, and relationship difficulties.

Location: Student Hub, Aston Webb
Tel: 0121 414 5130
Counselling and Wellbeing Service website

Opening hours

Term-time: Monday–Friday, 9am–5pm (Evening appointments also available during term time)

Vacation: Monday–Friday, 9am–12.30pm and 1.30pm–5pm

title: Dentists
content:
You can find out which dentists' practices are close to your accommodation by visiting the NHS website. The nearest dental practice to the University’s main Edgbaston campus is the University and Dental Implant Centre:

5 Pritchatts Road
Edgbaston
Birmingham
B15 2QU

Tel: 0121 687 8882.

title: Disability and learning support
content:
The Disability and Learning Support Service offers a range of specialist advice and support to ensure you have the best possible experience at the University. If you have a study support need related to a disability, including specific learning difficulties or health conditions, we can help.

This may include arranging for extra time in exams, working with timetabling to ensure teaching and learning environments are fully accessible, organising library assistance, or liaising with schools and tutors to ensure you are supported in the best possible way to suit your individual needs.

Location: Student Hub, Aston Webb
Email: disability@bham.ac.uk
Tel: 0121 414 5130.
Disability and Learning Support Service

Opening hours

Term-time: Monday–Friday, 9am–5pm

Vacation: Monday–Friday, 9am–12.30pm and 1.30pm–5pm

title: Doctors
content:
The Department of Health states that you should register with a doctor near where you live for most of the year. Your home town doctor will still be able to offer you care as a temporary patient during vacations. You can find out which doctor's surgeries are close to your accommodation by visiting the NHS website.

Some surgeries have their own websites that allow you to pre-register online with them (you will need to go to the surgery to complete registration). The NHS website also has information on local dentists, opticians and pharmacies.

The nearest doctors’ surgery to the University’s main Edgbaston campus is the University Medical Practice.

5 Pritchatts Road
Edgbaston
Birmingham
B15 2QU

Tel: 0121 687 3055.

The Selly Oak Shuttle Bus service provides a link between the Edgbaston and Selly Oak campuses. This is a free service on production of your student or staff ID card.

View the Selly Oak Shuttle Bus timetable

In addition to this service the University provides students with subsidised travel on shuttle buses which travel between the Edgbaston campus and the student residences.

Go to the IT Service Desk

title: Job Zone
content:
You may need to work to cover your living expenses while you study. The Job Zone gives you access to hundreds of part-time and temporary vacancies, as well as employment information and advice just for students.

The University of Birmingham has its own dedicated recruitment agency, ‘Worklink’ which connects you to on campus casual work opportunities.

title: Library Just Ask
content:
Just Ask! is the University Library's chat service. Get a rapid response to your question.

If you have a question, why not speak to a librarian with our online chat facility.

Just Ask! is online 9am−7pm, Monday-Friday and 10am-6pm at weekends. Or you can also call: +44 (0) 121 414 5828

You can chat online to the Library Just Ask! staff via the Just Ask widget in the Library intranet

title: Library services
content:
You can use our Just Ask! chat service to send an instant message to the library, including queries about key texts for your subject, how to borrow items and how to access electronic resources. Both Just Ask! and FindIt@Bham (our ever growing collection of electronic resources – books, periodicals and databases) are available via the Library Services web pages or the my.library tab on the student portal.

Location: Main Library
+44 (0) 121 414 5828
Library Services website

Opening hours

See Library website

title: Live music
content:
Birmingham is a hive of entertainment, boasting more than 150 venues for live music offering something for even the most diverse tastes. The city’s musical activity ranges from independent venues offering intimate gigs featuring the best local musical talent to internationally recognised arenas hosting the biggest musical superstars all-year round. The city also has an annual jazz festival and one of Europe’s finest concert halls, home to the City of Birmingham’s Symphony Orchestra. Historically, the city is famed for its 1960s ‘Brum beat’ era of blues and rock music and is credited as the birthplace of heavy metal music, which provides an eclectic mix of live music opportunities today.

Further information about live gigs

title: Living @ Birmingham
content:
Providing your home from home throughout your time in Birmingham, Living is the University's accommodation service to support you with every stage of the accommodation process. Come and visit the Living shop in University Centre where our team of experienced staff are able to offer advice and guidance on accommodation and help you find the perfect home in either university owned accommodation or the private sector.

Living aim not only to help you find accommodation, but to also ensure you have an enjoyable living experience and encourage you to talk to them if you have any concerns about your accommodation. Living also offers a contract checking service for the private sector, giving you confidence in your landlord and ensuring you are aware of the terms.

Guild Lettings

Guild Lettings (formerly known as SHAC), run by the Guild of Students and working in partnership with the University, is a dedicated lettings agency just for students. Based in the Living shop in University Centre, Guild Lettings provide a FREE service to help students find quality houses owned by accredited landlords in the private sector.

Location: University Centre.
Tel: +44 (0) 121 414 8000
 Email: living@contacts.bham.ac.uk
Website: www.birmingham.ac.uk/accommodation
Facebook: www.facebook.com/birminghamaccommodation
Twitter: twitter.com/livingatbham

Opening hours

Monday 9am–5pm
Tuesday 10am-5pm
Wednesday - Friday 9am-5pm

title: Lost property
content:
Lost and found property should be reported to Security. They can be contacted on 0121 414 3114.

After three months any unclaimed lost property is passed on to Acorns Children's Charity for re-sale.

Any unclaimed bicycles are donated to a local school which is part of a scheme that provides the opportunity for visually impaired students to learn to cycle.

Location: Aston Webb Building.

Opening hours

Monday-Friday, 9am-4.30pm

title: Main library
content:
Our printed collections are housed in the Main Library and nine site libraries and resource centres.

An ever growing electronic collection of resources – books, periodicals, databases - is available via the campus network and externally through the Internet. By continually investing in technology, facilities, resources and people, we aim to support the high quality research and learning environment to which the University aspires.

title: Multi-faith Chaplaincy
content:
Drop in to chat with a Chaplain, to meet with friends from your own religious tradition or from other faiths, or just for a cup of tea. Chaplains can give you pastoral support or a listening ear for your problems. We can put you in touch with Chaplains from all the major religious traditions and also with a number of student-run faith and religious societies.

title: NUS Extra
content:
NUS Extra is the definitive student discount card with a range of exclusive discounts, offers and competitions designed to make student life more exciting, more memorable and more rewarding.

Get your NUS Extra card today

Go to the NUS Extra website, fill in the online form, upload a photo of yourself, pay by debit card and you’re done. Your card will be ready to collect from the Guild.

title: Nightline
content:
Nightline is a confidential, non-judgmental listening and information service run by students, for students. It is open every night of term, 6pm till 8am and provides an ear for any anxieties or queries students may have however big or small. Contact can be made through telephone, email, instant messenger, or drop in at St Francis Hall.

The drop in service runs from 6pm to midnight.

Location: St Francis Hall
Tel: 0800 027 4750.
Email: email@bhamnightline.co.uk
Find out more: Nightline website

title: Officer team
content:
Every year you get the chance to elect officers to lead the Guild. Each officer has a different remit and it’s their job to represent your views to improve your university experience.

The officer team includes sabbatical and non-sabbatical officers. Sabbatical officers take a year out after, or during, their studies. Non-sabbatical officers fulfil their roles whilst completing their studies.

Find out more: Guild Officer Team

title: Personal Skills Award
content:
The Personal Skills Award (PSA) is an award-winning scheme that provides evidence to employers of skills you have gained whilst at university, giving you a great advantage when job hunting.

You can either earn points for your extra-curricular activities, called the PSA (Activity), or attend an accredited series of employability modules, called the PSA (Modular).

title: Student ambassadors
content:
Student Ambassadors act as a student representative for the University during open days, school visits and campus tours.

They meet and greet parents and potential applicants during interview days, assist with visits to the campus by schools and colleges and give presentations about student life.

Ambassadors are paid on an hourly basis and work can be fitted in around other jobs and study commitments. Some hours are also available during vacation periods.

This is a competitive role, with a selection process and full training for successful applicants.

Collect an application form from Job Zone at the beginning of the autumn term.

title: Student enquiries
content:
Visit studenthelp to get help with student admin queries including ID cards, transcripts, programme changes, withdrawal and restart, contact detail changes and more.

Welcome 2015

Our Welcome website has all the background information you need as you start your course, including help for registration, finding your way around campus and the city, and welcome events.

title: Student funding
content:
Funding, Graduation and Awards provides information, advice and guidance to prospective and current students, parents, guardians and staff on all student loans, grants and financial support allowances available and are responsible for the management and administration of a variety of funding streams for both undergraduate and postgraduate students.

This includes funding for trainee teachers; the Chamberlain Award for undergraduate students that have a household income below £36,000; the University’s Student Hardship Fund to help students who have genuine and unavoidable financial difficulties and are struggling with their living costs despite having received all financial support available to them.

There are numerous scholarship opportunities available at the University and you can search to see which you may eligible to apply for by looking that the Undergraduate funding database or the Postgraduate funding database.

The office also provides information about the cost of coming to the University, your funding options and budgeting tips.

Advisors at the Guild of Students can also provide assistance completing hardship fund applications and advice on managing financial difficulties and budgeting.

Contact us via the online enquiry system.

title: Student mentors
content:
The Student Mentor Scheme provides advice and guidance to all students living in University accommodation. The Scheme can help with a variety of issues including: Shared living and accommodation related issues, your academic course, financial matters and your general wellbeing whilst studying at the university.

The Guild of Students recognises more than 170 groups and societies catering for a wide range of interests and activities.

Search for a Club or society at the Guild of Students website.

For further information on student groups and societies email studentgroups@guild.bham.ac.uk or visit the Student Development department in the Guild basement.

title: Study spaces
content:
From large computer clusters to private group study zones, there’s a wide range of study spaces on campus which are open to all students.

Find out more about study spaces including opening hours.

Study spaces pdf map

title: Subject support
content:
Subject Advisors are available to provide help, advice, training, support and documentation to students and staff undertaking research, project work, essays and/or dissertations.

Subject Advisors can offer the following support:

  • Introduce library services and resources
  • Help to identify basic training in key databases and information sources in your subject area
  • Explain the principles of literature searching
  • Troubleshoot complex/systematic literature reviews
  • Introduce referencing software
  • Help to keep you up to date with research
  • Arrange 1-1 sessions at a mutually convenient time. These may be conducted in person, via email, over the phone, or online via Skype. Appointments will last for a maximum 45 minutes. These sessions will be initially provided on a limited offer of 2 sessions per student, per semester.

What Subject Advisors can't do:

  • Conduct your literature search(es) for you
  • Offer any qualitative assessment of references found through a literature search
  • Write or proof-read your assignments
  • Offer an opinion on any mark that you might receive for your written work
  • Become involved in decisions relating to academic regulations, such as extenuating circumstances.

Find out the advisor for your subject

Book a one-to-one appointment or get online help via Skype

title: Swimming pool
content:
The pool is equipped to accommodate swimming galas with 6 lanes, starting blocks, turning boards and anti-wave lane ropes. It also has a hoist to assist disabled swimmers.

Pool sessions are separated into lengths and general. Members eligible to use the pool can do so at any time within these sessions.

Student membership prices

Find out more about the swimming pool

title: Taxis
content:
Be sure to book a taxi and don’t be tempted to jump into the nearest one. If you don’t book a taxi and it is not a black cab you will not be insured and your safety home cannot be guaranteed. Remember, legally, only black cabs can pick you up off the street without a booking. Any other taxi which does this is breaking the law.

Castle Cars fares and bookings
Tel: +44 (0) 121 472 2222
Current student set fares
Web: www.castle-cars.co.uk

Castle Cars are the only taxi firm that the University endorses. In emergencies, you can use your University ID card as payment (up to £10) if you have no money but need to get home safely.

title: Timetables
content:
Timetables for lectures and other events held in centrally-booked teaching spaces are published online for each academic year.

  • Search online timetables for the current academic year
  • Students can also view personal timetables via the my.bham portal
  • More about web timetables

title: Trains
content:
The University is the only mainland British university to have its own railway station, 'University', on campus.

'University' is only two stops and about eight minutes from Birmingham New Street, the region's main train hub.

Train times and tickets: National Rail Enquiries

Local station live train departures

  • University station live departures
  • New Street station live departures
  • Selly Oak station live departures

title: Volunteering
content:
Over 200 volunteering opportunities to suit your interests, your passions and your timetable. Volunteer on a regular or one-off basis, with established charities such as Oxfam or student-led projects.

Find out more: Volunteering

title: Wireless network
content:
If you have a wireless enabled device, you can gain access to the University wireless network.

Find out how to set up WiFi

title: my bham
content:
my.bham is your online portal, providing a single point of access to information and resources. Login using your University username and password to gain access to:

  • University email
  • Canvas
  • Online registration
  • Library FindIt - online catalogue
  • Library help - Just Ask!
  • Exam past papers
  • Exam timetables
  • Exam results
  • Campus news
  • Study support
  • and much more...

Go to my.bham
